title: MadR - Madison R Programming UseRs Group: Hacking Your Environment: Tips and Tricks for Efficient Workflow.
group: MadR - Madison R Programming UseRs Group
description:
Mark K will be giving a talk on making an efficient R workflow:

Start 2020 off right by developing good workflow habits. How much time do you take to set up your environment before you begin working? In this talk I'll argue that some quality attention to your set up and teardown practice goes a long way to convert your messy r-studio garage lab into a refined space station. We'll cover basics like working directory and .RProject files and more nuanced tricks like loading works in progess and preprocessed output files, setting global themes to streamline your reports' graphical styles and other things. It's time to Marie-Kondo your code.

title: Seattle useR Group (R Programming Language): Shiny in January at Ookla HQ!
description:
*** UPDATE ****
Due to snow/ice in the area, we are pushing the meetup to Wednesday, January 22nd! We hope to see you there!
****

Shiny is a great tool for R programmers and has a lot of functionality. This evening we have a fantastic treat to learn more about how Shiny has been used for industry.

First we will have some speakers from Ookla talking about they use shiny for fact-finding missions.

Next we have talks from Heather Nolis and Jacqueline Nolis. Heather Nolis is a Machine Learning Engineer at T-Mobile. Jacqueline Nolis is the Principal Data Scientist at Nolis, LLC. Jacqueline and Heather will discuss how they use, customize, and deploy shiny applications!

Date:[masked]
(No Longer -[masked]-- due to snow)

Location: Ookla HQ, downtown Seattle

Doors open: 5:30pm for social time

The first presentation will start at 6:00PM. After the presentations there will be more social time!

David Hall and Katie Jolly:
Shiny is an R package that makes it easy to build interactive applications straight from R. The Ookla Data Science team hosts frequently used fact-finding tools and RMarkdown reports in a custom-built Shiny deployment. In the first half of the meetup, Ookla's Data Science team will discuss some of the challenges with building a limited feature version of Rstudio Connect then provide a functionality demo.

Heather Nolis (Machine Learning Engineer at T-Mobile) and
Jacqueline Nolis (Principal Data Scientist at Nolis, LLC):
Making machine learning models is a core part of a data scientist’s job, but that work will only be well-received by executives if they can understand the models. The AI @ T-Mobile team has been lucky enough to get funding and people for our projects by convincing vice presidents to trust our work using fun, interactive Shiny demos with T-Mobile style and branding. In this talk we’ll cover our process of creating Shiny demos, the tools we use to make them look T-Mobile magenta, and the technology we use to quickly deploy them (spoiler, it involves Docker). We’ll also show off a few of the interactive demos we made with some audience participation.

We look forward to seeing you at this sure to be fantastic meetup!

Please email/message Ellis Hughes if you have ideas for future Meetups you would like to see or organize.

title: Seattle useR Group (R Programming Language): Relational data models with the dm package
description:
At this meetup we have a great presentation from Kirill Müller of cynkra. Fresh off of RStudio::Conf, lets keep the R enthusiasm going!

Kirill will present {dm}, a new package that facilitates working with multiple tables. Three principal use cases can be identified: consuming a data model, building in-memory or local data models without relying on relational databases, and preparing consistent relational data models for consumption by others. Based on these use cases, he outlines the features of this package and discusses future development. The presentation will be interactive with live coding and a script that attendants can run during or after the presentation. The package is available on GitHub at https://krlmlr.github.io/dm.

Kirill works on the boundary between data and computer science with more than 20 years of software engineering experience. He enjoys working with and contributing to the R ecosystem since 2012. In 2018 he joined forces with Christoph Sax to found cynkra, a Zurich-based consultancy that helps businesses and government institutions better understand their valuable data and communicate the insights, with a focus on the R ecosystem. https://cynkra.com

If you are wanting to have your own meetup to discuss the cool ways you are using R, reach out to Ellis Hughes via Meetup.com!

title: R-Ladies RTP: #tidytuesday Work Group
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! Work individually or with the group and end the evening by sharing your work.

We'll explore the PetFinder data set available here: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2019/2019-12-17 . You can read more about the data set and associated online article via that link too.

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:15 pm Meet & Greet
6:15 - 7:30 pm #tidytuesday
7:30 - 8:00 pm Discussion

This is a great opportunity to meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build up your GitHub/Twitter/data science portfolio!

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post: https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together!

What should I bring?
Please bring your own laptop (fully-charged!) and all learning materials you want to use. If you have time, please look at the data set beforehand and think about some questions you'd like to answer with it.

Where will it take place?
Cocoa Cinnamon Lakewood

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: Hamburg R User Group: Relational data models with the dm package
description:
Hi everyone, we are happy to announce our first meetup in 2020. As usual the meetup will be open for all to attend, and newcomers / beginners are very welcome.

The agenda for this meetup is:

18.30 Open Doors
18.50 Welcome / AOB
19.00 "Relational data models with the dm package" - Kirill Müller (cynkra)
19.45 Break
20:00 Meet the Expert: Kirill Müller
20.30 Cool down Beer

At this meetup Kirill Müller will present his new dm package, which is briefly described below.

** Relational data models with the dm package - Kirill Müller (cynkra)
Kirill will present {dm}, a new package that facilitates working with multiple tables. Three principal use cases can be identified: consuming a data model, building in-memory or local data models without relying on relational databases, and preparing consistent relational data models for consumption by others. Based on these use cases, he outlines the features of this package and discusses future development. The presentation will be interactive with live coding and a script that attendants can run during or after the presentation. The package is available on GitHub at https://krlmlr.github.io/dm.

About the speaker: Kirill works on the boundary between data and computer science with more than 20 years of software engineering experience. He enjoys working with and contributing to the R ecosystem since 2012. In 2018 he joined forces with Christoph Sax to found cynkra, a Zurich-based consultancy that helps businesses and government institutions better understand their valuable data and communicate the insights, with a focus on the R ecosystem. https://cynkra.com

title: R-Ladies Seattle: R configuration and purrr
description:
Kara Woo will present a workshop on R configuration, maintaining R, and how to repeat yourself with purrr. The workshop will cover the 5th and 8th modules of the two-day What They Forgot to Teach You About R workshop (https://rstudio-conf-2020.github.io/what-they-forgot/).

This workshop is designed for experienced R and RStudio users who want to (re)design their R lifestyle. You should take this workshop if you’ve been using R for a while, you feel like writing R code is not what’s holding you back the most, and you want to learn more about your R installation.

This is a hands-on workshop, so please bring a laptop with a current version of R and RStudio installed. RSVPing helps us know how many people to expect, but is not required.

This event is NOT sponsored by The Seattle Public Library.

title: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday: MLDM Monday | 用 ggplot2 畫選舉圖表
group: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday
description:
[Topic]
用 ggplot2 畫選舉圖表

[Abstract]
這次想跟大家分享如何用 R 當中的 ggplot2 套件畫出選舉圖表/草圖，這些圖表可以直接使用，也可以另外輸出 SVG ，在其他軟體中後製。
實際使用的資料有兩部分，第一部份是 2020 台灣總統與立委選舉資料，第二部分是台大 2015~2017 的學代選舉與出席率資料。
因為著重選舉圖表，所以地圖部分會包含一般的地圖、蜂巢圖(hexmap)、示意地圖(cartogram)、議會席次圖；非地圖部分包含常見的散點圖、堆疊長條圖等。

[Agenda]
- 地圖 - 2020選舉
- 非地圖 - 台大學代選舉與出席
- QA

[對象]
- 適合對 R 語言有一定基礎的人
- 適合使用過 ggplot2 套件、想知道更多樣圖表製作的人
- 不適合想產出設計師等級超精美圖表的人
- 不適合想聽選情分析的人

[Speaker]
Dennis Tseng，台大工商管理學系在學生，目前在 Yahoo Taiwan 擔任實習分析師，對統計、商業分析、資料分析、資料新聞、資訊視覺化都很有興趣，超級喜歡 R！

title: R-Ladies Strasbourg: Comment sont gérer les données manquantes dans une régression PLS ?
description: Les données manquantes sont présentes dans beaucoup de domaines de recherche. Plusieurs méthodes ont été développées pour les traiter. La méthode d'imputation est le processus qui permet de gérer les données manquantes avant d'estimer les paramètres d'un modèle. La régression PLS est un modèle qui va permettre de les gérer. C'est une méthode qui est basée sur deux algorithmes (SIMPLS ou NIPALS) qui peuvent être utilisés pour fournir les estimations des paramètres des modèles. La régression PLS est très efficace pour analyser les relations de cause à effet entre les variables réponses et les composantes. L'algorithme NIPALS fournit des estimations sur de données incomplètes sans imputation. Notre objectif est étudier l’influence de la proportion de données manquantes sur l’estimation du nombre de composantes dans une régression PLS pour une hypothèse MCAR.

title: R-Ladies London, Ontario: RMarkdown and Bookdown for Dissertating
description:
This month's meet up, Thea Knowles will return to lead us through an interactive tutorial on preparing to write a dissertation using RMarkdown and Bookdown. This month also marks 3 awesome years of R-Ladies London!

RMarkdown allows you to seamlessly integrate R code and narrative text as well as specify formatting options across multiple document output types (docx, pdf, html). Bookdown serves as a means to combining multiple RMarkdown files into a final book*.

This workshop will feature a crash course on RMarkdown and will cover the following: reference management in RMarkdown, tips for a modular workflow, integrating templates (like Western's thesis templates) into RMarkdown/bookdown documents, and more.

*"Despite the package name containing the word “book”, bookdown is not only for books. The “book” can be anything that consists of multiple R Markdown documents meant to be read in a linear sequence, such as course handouts, study notes, a software manual, a thesis, or even a diary." - Yihui Xie https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/

title: R-Ladies Boston: January Event: Data Gets Personal
description:
In this talk, Louisa Smith will describe her experience collecting and analyzing some very personal data: data relating to her breast cancer treatment. From digging deep into her health insurance website to tracking her drug-induced hot flashes, Louisa will detail how she ended up with the data in this powerful twitter thread: https://twitter.com/louisahsmith/status/1179429494664388609. Whether you are interested in learning more about collecting data about yourself or just want to know how R can serve both as a tool to cope during stressful times and as a tool for advocacy, join us!

Louisa is currently a PhD candidate in epidemiology at Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health. She has been using R for five years in both her professional and personal lives. You can find her at https://www.louisahsmith.com and on twitter @louisahsmith.

Pizza will be served (thanks to BMS!) and the presentation will begin at 6:15

title: R-Ladies New York: R-Ladies Code-llaboration Hangout
description:
We'll kick off the year with a hands-on working session where we'll work together on our own projects or tutorials.

Come in curious about a subject or looking to make progress on a project you're working on!

We'll divide ourselves into groups who'll be working on similar topics, and we'll have prompts and tutorials at hand for those who don't have a particular project in mind.

We believe that by collaborating with other R-Ladies who share your curiosity you’ll get much further than you would at home with google, and that even if you don’t have a set goal you’ll learn through sharing and receiving tips and tricks.

All experience levels welcome!

We'll have five groups, for those working on projects related to:
1 - Making your website with R and blogdown
2 - Building a package
3 - Tidy Tuesday
4 - Forecasting with time series data
5 - Everything else!

Thank you to AT&T for hosting us and the R Conference and Lander Analytics for sponsoring pizza.

title: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup: Data Science North East: January Meeting
group: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup
description:
Details
Schedule:

6:00 - Food and drinks
6:30 - Matthew Forshaw (NCL Uni): Best practice in reproducible data science in R
7:15 - Matt Edwards: An Introduction to Interpreting Machine Learning Models

An Introduction to Interpreting Machine Learning Models

Abstract: The most accurate predictive models in Machine Learning are often the least interpretable (e.g. random forest) and the most interpretable models are often the least accurate (e.g. linear regression). Hence, there is often a conflict between accuracy and interpretability. We want the most accurate models but don’t want to sacrifice interpretability. In this talk, I discuss this conflict and some new methods in Machine Learning for interpreting ANY predictive model so you do not have to sacrifice predictive accuracy. A package (https://github.com/mt-edwards/xrayspecs) is also introduced that provides these new methods for R programmers.

title: Meetup de Grupo de Usuarios de R de Málaga: 11ª reunión de Grupo de Usuarios de R de Málaga
group: Meetup de Grupo de Usuarios de R de Málaga
description:
Hola, comenzamos el año 2020 con un Taller. Para próximos talleres iremos insertando formación de algunos paquetes R.

Jueves 30 de enero a las 19:00. La duración será de una hora y media aproximadamente.

Título: Random Forests con aplicación a investigación biomédica
Autor: Gabriel Aguilera

Enlace de cartel (difundir la charla, reenviando este correo y/o el enlace):

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1JYTDnGqbRQXGc7Ii822eMuIOCHTGhych/view?usp=sharing

"Los árboles de decisión y la técnica denominada Random Forest están entre los métodos más interesantes, eficientes y usados en ciencia de datos.

Se utilizan en problemas de regresión, clasificación, etc.
(ver https://bookdown.org/content/2031/ensambladores-random-forest-parte-i.html)

Gabriel es profesor del Departamento de Matemática Aplicada, conocedor de muchos lenguajes de análisis y programación, nos va a contar su experiencia con R y cómo se usa actualmente en un centro de investigación biomédico.

Vamos a trabajar en el taller con un problema real de diagnosis médica con datos reales que vamos a tener la suerte de poder usar. El taller pretende enseñar a usar las técnicas de árboles de decisión y de random forest. "

Lugar: Laboratorio[masked] (sitio habitual de anteriores charlas).

Recomendación - traer vuestro portátil los que podáis y tengáis acceso a la wifi de la UMA. Seguimos renovando laboratorio (en 2020 esperamos que ya toque), para los que no tengáis acceso a la wifi de la UMA, usaremos los ordenadores que tenemos. Dar las gracias al Departamento de Matemática Aplicada por su colaboración.

Límite de asistentes: 50 plazas

Como siempre, luego una/s cerveza/s y/o refresco/s.

Com siempre, si conocéis a alguien que se apuntó antes en el grupo de usuarios pero no está en Meetup, por favor, indicarle que a partir de ahora trabajamos para coordinarnos usando Meetup.

Manda esta información a interesados en nuestro grupo. Enlace de cartel del grupo de R:

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1YjmB79A7rASn6ib0YsJH8D6qXnR_XFvc/view?usp=sharing

(difundir el cartel del grupo)

¡Un saludo!

title: LA R users group: Getting better at R: Learning More Packages More Deeply & Hyper-parameter Tuning
description:
Talk 1:
Speaker: Daniel Jacobs (@djacobs7), Senior Director, Data Science Engineering at Age Of Learning. Website: www.dontyouremember.com

Title: Getting better at R By Learning More Packages More Deeply

Abstract:

Learning R means learning dozens of different packages and methods. CRAN has over 10,000 packages, and it's not always clear what's important to learn next. Once you decide what to learn, it's can be difficult to commit the important methods to memory so that you can use them easily over the next weeks or months. This talk walks you through strategies for deciding what to learn, and then committing them to memory with the spaced repetition algorithm. It gives an example of discovering what packages to learn via code analysis. Finally, it describes the development of the remembR package, which lets you study R directly in R.

Talk 2:
Speaker: Emil Hvitfeldt (@Emil_Hvitfeldt), Research Programmer at USC and Co-organizer of @laeRusers

Title: Hyper-parameter Tuning with Tune Package

Abstract:
Many statistical and machine learning models have parameters that can directly be inferred from the data. The newly released tune package is part of the tidymodels framework and allows you to do hyper-parameter tuning.

Code of Conduct: https://github.com/laRusers/codeofconduct

title: Colchester R Meetup: 2020 intro to and best of R!
description:
Welcome to 2020!

We are going to kick off the New Year with a triple header of great talks. These sessions have been designed to be a gentle but informative introduction to those who are excited to learn about the R programming language.

Session 1: "Learning and using R as a beginner" - Leyla Yaltiligil, Department of Mathematics, University of Essex

This talk will be about my journey from pure mathematics into the foray of programming and using software within my degree, ‘recreationally’ and also learning new programming languages to practice for roles that interest me. I am a final year Undergraduate Maths student and I’m fairly new to programming but I have really enjoyed my optimisation and data analysis modules and would like to explore R more.

Session 2: "Making the switch: One psychologist's journey from SPSS/Excel to R with 'basic stuff' along the way" - Dr. Vanessa Loaiza, Department of Psychology, University of Essex

Session 3: "Best of R" - Alasdair Clarke, Department of Psychology, University of Essex

Snacks and beverages provided courtesy of IADS: https://www.essex.ac.uk/centres-and-institutes/institute-for-analytics-and-data-science

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Power BI and March Madness
description:
# Introduction

Power BI is a business analytics solution that lets you visualize data, share insights, or embed them in an app or website. It allows easy access to connect to hundreds of data sources, create dashboards and reports. Power BI, can run R scripts and create data models and visualizations. Suresh will give a demo on how you can use your R stills to interact with Power BI.

March Madness, the NCAA basketball tournament that takes us by storm every March is right around the corner. ncaahoopR is an R package for working with NCAA Basketball Play-by-Play Data. It scrapes play-by-play data and returns it to the user in a tidy format and allows the user to explore the data with assist networks and in-game win-probability charts.

Come early, network and enjoy the food.

# Schedule

6:30 - 6:50 Networking
6:50 - 7:00 Welcome & general announcement
7:00 - 7:30 Using R in Power BI
7:30 - 8:00 Basketball: Let's Explore March Madness with ncaahoopR
8:00 - 8:30 Networking and Clean-up

# Talk 1

## Title: Using R in Power BI
## Speaker: Suresh Datla
## Abstract

Power BI is a business analytics solution that lets you visualize data, share insights, or embed them in an app or website. It allows easy access to connect to hundreds of data sources, create dashboards and reports. Power BI, can run R scripts and create data models and visualizations. Suresh will give a demo on how you can use your R stills to interact with Power BI.

# Talk 2

## Title: Basketball: Let's Explore March Madness with ncaahoopR
## Speaker: Luke Morris
## Abstract

March Madness is right around the corner. Whether your interest in college basketball lasts for one month or all year round, the ncaahoopR package can catch you up on the teams or games you care about, and maybe even keep you alive in that office pool a while longer.

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Building R Packages
description:
***Bring your laptop***

# Introduction

This month will be an introduction to working with packages. This used to be a challenging task but with RStudio and the packages, devtools and rtools it is pretty easy. Peter Stemler is going to introduce give a hands-on tutorial to create a package. We'll dive into the structure of a package and what each directory and file does and cover how to document your code, add datasets, export/import functions, check, build and use your package in your other projects.

Make sure that you bring a laptop with RStudio installed along with devtools and the roxygen2 package. If you are on a Windows machine you may want to also install the rtools package.

Come early, network and enjoy the food. Do not forget your laptop with R and Python installed.

# Schedule

6:30 - 6:50 Networking
6:50 - 7:00 Welcome & general announcement
7:00 - 8:00 Peter Stemler: Building R Packages
8:00 - 8:30 Networking and Clean-up

title: The Chicago R User Group (CRUG): Double Feature: Many Ways to Lasso & Object Oriented Programming in R
description:
We have another exciting meetup, featuring Jared Lander, author of author of "R for Everyone" as well as Anthony Shook, Lead Data Scientist at Jellyvision Labs, inc.

Doors open at 5:30 talks begin at 6 pm. Vittles will be served, sponsored by IBM!

Jared Lander: Many ways to Lasso
Anthony Shook, Ph.D: Object-Oriented Programming in R

Anthony started using R more than 10 years ago because he hated Excel, and has never looked back! A former Northwestern Professor, Anthony will teach us about S3, S4, and R6 object oriented systems in R. https://www.jellyvision.com/ https://www.linkedin.com/in/ajshook/

Jared P. Lander is Chief Data Scientist of Lander Analytics, the Organizer of the New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup and the New York, Washington DC and Dublin R Conferences and an Adjunct Professor at Columbia Business School. He is the author of R for Everyone, a book about R Programming geared toward Data Scientists and Non-Statisticians alike. His writings on statistics can be found at jaredlander.com.
The Lasso remains an excellent statistical learning technique for modeling data sets containing many variables/features. While glmnet remains the classic package for applying the approach using R, Jared will show us how one can Lasso with additional R packages interfacing Keras, lars, Stan, xgboost, spark, and quadratic programming.

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group
description:
Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: St. Petersburg R User Group: SPbR #16
description:
Андрей Головин, ведущий инженер в компании Electrolux

Детектирование события с помощью классификации временных рядов.

Расскажу про задачу детектирования появления события для данных в виде временных рядов с использованием трех подходов: классические алгоритмы классификации, DL и классификация на основе формы сигнала.

Никитин Николай, инженер Национального центра когнитивных разработок Университета ИТМО.

Как эффективно разработать современную модель кредитного скоринга на R

Я расскажу, с какими сложностями столкнулась наша команда при разработке модели кредитного скоринга и какие подходы были использованы для ее эффективного решения с помощью R.

****
Расписание:
To be announced

Будет запись и трансляция.

*****
Самая актуальная информация, материалы и записи докладов в группе https://vk.com/spbrug

Обратите внимание: в этот раз мы снова встречаемся в новом офисе JetBrains у метро Беговая.

description:

group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
Sync up your interactive dashboards with crosstalk AND rstudio::conf 2020 recap!

Abstract:
You can build amazing interactive dashboards in R Markdown using the flexdashboard package and HTML widgets. Sometimes, though, you want all your interactive components to synchronize their outputs to user inputs instead of all acting independently. That’s exactly what the crosstalk package does. Carl Howe, RStudio’s Director of Education, will show attendees how to use the crosstalk package on RStudio Cloud, and each of you can try it out for yourselves. When Carl demonstrated this package during his R Markdown and Interactive Dashboards workshop, many of the attendees said this one package was worth the entire price of the workshop; we think you’ll find it worth knowing about.

Carl and Rachael Dempsey will also recap the highlights of rstudio::conf 2020 held in San Francisco on January 27-30, 2020, and they’ll provide links to the conference content so that you can download many of the materials yourselves.

title: Winnipeg R User Group: Winnipeg R User Group - Meeting #12
description:
Winnipeg R User Group Meeting #12 - Reprex and Datapasta

One day you will need to ask for help on questions regarding coding, research design, or statistical analysis, including choosing proper machine learning models.

'reprex' and 'datapasta' will render your data so that it's friendly to ask questions over forums when you do not have the knowledge or someone immediate to help you.

'reprex', by Jenny Bryan, is part of the Tidyverse; and stands for “Reproducible Example”.

'datapasta' allows for very easy copying and pasting your data; and is used easily with 'reprex'.

These tools are excellent, especially if you have errors in your code and have no idea why they are happening, and you need to ask someone for help.

In this meeting, Marcello Nesca will demonstrate how the use of 'reprex' and 'datapasta' tools are “Best Practices” for data reproducibility.

Please bring a laptop computer if you wish to do the hands-on exercises at this meeting.

title: Saint Louis R User Group: Introduction to RecordLinkage
description:
By: Alexander Mueller

A large organization might maintain multiple databases containing different types of information on their customers, patients, jet engine parts, etc. At scale, it is sometimes quite difficult to figure out all the records across all the databases that refer to a particular entity (often an individual person) in the real world. Record linkage is the body of knowledge about how to approach this situation in its thornier manifestations and naturally this body of knowledge has its own specialized algorithms and software tools.

You can easily verify that the speaker has a very common first and last name, and hopefully this will give you a sense of why record linkage at scale is not a trivial exercise.

I will give a Step 0 introduction to R's RecordLinkage library including technical and business perspectives on "Who Cares?", an overview of just what is the library, a walkthrough of the data intuition around some pre-packaged synthetic datasets, and an application of the library to some simple problems posed to the included data.

title: Bay Area useR Group (R Programming Language): "Official" February 2020 BARUG Meetup
group: Bay Area useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
Our February meetup will be held in conjunction with the Biotech-Pharma R User Meetup. This is our first joint meeting and I believe it will be a special event.

However, in addition to sending a positive RSVP on this page you must also register here: https://bbsw-tickets.ticketleap.com/bbswuser-r-user-meetup/

Agenda:
6:30 - Reception and Networking
7:00 - Announcements
7:10 - Tony Chang - Validating R in the Biotech-Pharma Industry
7:30 - Doug KelKhoff - Building Trust in Open Source Scientific Software: Grassroots Software Validation for R
8:05 - Dan Putler - Understanding Opioid Prescribing Behavior in England

#######
Tony Chang
Title: Validating R in the Biotech-Pharma Industry

SAS has been the gold standard system for statistical analysis and reporting in the Biotech-Pharma industry. Whereas R has been increasingly used by data science communities. Biotech-Pharma can take many advantages of R, such as data visualization to analyze and present clinical trial data for decision making and regulatory submission. However per guidance, computerized systems used in clinical research in a regulatory setting must be validated, and validating R is extremely challenging because of the nature of an open source environment. This presentation will discuss the validation requirements per regulatory guidance for both system setup and application development. In addition, we will share our experience of building validated and non-validated R distributions at BioMarin, which include 1) the infrastructure of the R platform, and 2) key components of R validation process: the package management process, and package validation framework. Our exploratory work suggests that with an appropriate system infrastructure and process setup, validating R in the Biotech-Pharma industry is achievable.

###########
Doug KelKhoff
Building Trust in Open Source Scientific Software: Grassroots Software Validation for R

Many regulated industries are at a turning point in their adoption of open source tools. To stay competitive, these companies must make use of open source tooling, which often have the first or most well adopted implementations of novel methods. Likewise, as the tooling around open source development has improved, the tools have followed, to the point that most recent graduates have roots in open source languages and prioritize publishing methods with open source implementations. This form of software development is quite new to many regulated industries, and the decades-long processes that govern software validation are being strained to accommodate the influx of community code.

I'll discuss ongoing work to build shared, cross-industry tooling for R package validation, how open source tools can be reproducibly delivered for regulators, and how these two pieces combine to provide a cross-industry mechanism to deliver reproducible results with.

############
Dan Putler
# Understanding Opioid Prescribing Behavior in England

I make use of both the R spdep and splm packages, coupled with the Alteryx analytics platform, to develop a spatial panel model to examine the drivers of prescribing behavior for opioid analgesics on the part of general practice physicians in England, relying on data from the Office of National Statistics for England and Wales, the National Health Service of England, and the commercial data provider MB-Research.

The analysis reveals that socioeconomic and demographic characteristics of an area play a major role in opioid prescription rates among physicians, which are consistent with Case and Deaton's findings of "deaths of despair" in the US. However, strong spatial dependence patterns are also at play, which indicate that there are systematic differences in physicians' willingness to prescribe opioids across England. This suggests that the traditional public health approach of providing regional physician training could be useful in lowering opioid prescription rates and related opioid overdose deaths.

title: Melbourne Users of R Network (MelbURN): Text Analytics with StarSpace in R
description:
Our series of talks continue with a talk on NLP embeddings. Hope to see you there. Big thanks to Eliiza for hosting and sponsoring food.

Text Analytics with StarSpace in R:
In this talk we will discuss how Bunnings implemented a Natural Language Processing technique called StarSpace which was developed by the Facebook AI Research team. In industry, messy data is the norm, but what about data with messy labels? We use the TagSpace algorithm (from StarSpace) to learn feature representations for short textual documents that takes advantage of an abundance of inconsistently applied labels.

Bio:
Ben Phillips is a Melbourne based Data Scientist with experience working in Education, Insurance and Retail. In his free time he enjoys writing Data Science articles, implementing the latest Natural Language Processing models, experimenting with Evolutionary Algorithms and participating in the occasional Kaggle competition. Outside the data space, you might find Ben jumping on a trampoline, experimenting with savoury baking or curled up with a book.

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: Analysing Multistage Survey Data Using R
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
For the second talk in February we are very excited to have R Core member Thomas Lumley talking about the {survey} package.

For the February 4th talk with Kirill Müller please visit https://www.meetup.com/nyhackr/events/267493644

Thank you to New York Presbyterian for hosting.

About the Talk:
Multistage surveys run by all levels of government and academic research groups are a rich source of data. Traditionally, their analysis involved specialised software (and even specialised hardware); one aim of survey research in recent decades has been to make survey analysis relatively boring, so that it can be done safely by people with domain expertise. I will talk about the R survey package, which just had its 16th birthday. The package allows for exploratory analysis and modelling, and supports research into more efficient estimation in two-phase samples.

About Thomas:
Thomas Lumley is originally from Australia, and was at the University of Washington in Seattle for 15 years. He is now Professor of Biostatistics at the University of Auckland. His research interests include study design in epidemiology, semiparametric theory, computing and graphics, and genomics. Thomas blogs about statistics in the media at statschat.org.nz and about other topics at notstatschat.rbind.io. He is a Fellow of the Royal Society of New Zealand and the American Statistical Association, and a member of R Core, and has taught short courses on R in thirteen time zones.

Pizza (https://bit.ly/pizzapoll) begins at 6:30, the talk starts at 7, then after we head to the local bar.

title: Vienna<-R: Vienna<-R 2020 February
description:
Dear ViennaR members,

We start the new decade with a hot topic in our community: R in production.
Our speakers are Thomas Strehl, Rudolf Pailer, Thomas Weinrich and Mario Annau showing different ways of deploying R models into production.
The Meetup is hosted at IBM Austria (Obere Donaustraße 95) and cool drinks are secured for a lively discussion and networking session afterwards :)

TOPICS

1. Thomas Strehl, Rudolf Pailer, Thomas Weinrich: Aspects of bringing R based machine learning to the enterprise

2. Mario Annau: Deployment of machine learning models using RStudio Connect and the cloud.

DETAILS

1. The enterprise requires Machine Learning to advance from it's 'magic blackbox' nimbus into a well understood and governed asset that evolves from and interacts with enterprise processes. In particular the core assets of machine learning, that is the data, the model creation and verification process, the scoring engine and all interactions with other enterprise applications, need to be subjected to strict version and quality control to ensure traceability and compliance compatibility.

2. Case study showing the creation and deployment of a machine learning model as REST-API and Shiny-app into production using RStudio connect. Alternatively, showing fast API cloud deployments using Qbits: https://www.quantargo.com/qbits

See you there!

Greetings,
ViennaR organizers

title: R-Ladies Resistencia-Corrientes: Nos visita FLOR: Aprendemos a hacer aplicaciones interactivas con Shiny!!!
R-Ladies Chicago: R-Ladies Project Night
description:
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project focused on using tidyverse packages to clean, wrangle, tidy, and plot a new dataset every Tuesday.

We will be using a dataset from the TidyTuedsay Github (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday)
that has been tamed, but does not always adhere to “tidy” data principles. Our goal is to have you take a look at the raw data, and generate either a copy of the original plot or a novel take on the data! You can obviously use whatever techniques you feel are appropriate, but the data will be organized in a way that tidyverse tools will work well!

Schedule
6-6:30 -- Food and drinks, Intros & Announcements
6:30-7:30 -- R TidyTuesday Project Night
7:30-8:00-- Socializing/Networking/Hanging out/Chillin'

Additionally, please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

title: R-Ladies Chicago: Career Series Part 1: Using R to Land the Job, a Resume Building Tutorial
description:
Welcome to the kick-off of our three-part career series! Over the next three months, we will host events to further develop your skillset and data science network.

Whether or not you're on the job hunt, your resume is an extension of your professional self, so it is important to keep your resume fresh. For our kick-off, our co-organizer Scarlett Winters will lead a tutorial on how to build your resume using pagedown. You will walk away from this tutorial with the skills to prove to employers you know how to code in R well before your interview!

*Prerequisites:
We ask that R-Ladies who are interested in this event please install:
- R:
https://www.r-project.org/

- R Studio:
https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

- Pagedown package, information found here: https://github.com/rstudio/pagedown
https://pagedown.rbind.io/

Additionally, if you have no background with Git or Github, we *strongly* recommend you take a look at modules 4-8 of the free Happy Git with R book (https://happygitwithr.com/github-acct.html) and follow the instructions to get yourself set up ahead of time to reduce pain the day of. If you need help with this, please come early so we can help you in person.

The repo for this event can be found here, and will be updated with more information as we get closer to the event date:
https://github.com/rladies-chicago/2020-02-26-pagedown-tutorial

title: Campus useR Group Frankfurt: February meeting: Show your plot!
description:
base-R, ggplot2 and maybe even lattice... one of R's strongest selling points is its enormous power to craft and automate hand-tailored data visualization. The possibilities seem endless – and so are the challenges to get every last tiny little detail implemented. :-)

For our February meeting, we would like to show our plots that we are most proud of and seek help for those we aren't too happy with yet. So if you can join us, feel free to bring a plot, plot idea or visualization problem of your own to share and discuss.

As always, our meeting is open to R users of all backgrounds and at all levels of expertise. So even if you haven't created plots in R before, come join and share your ideas and questions!

title: R-Ladies Boulder: R Ladies Boulder Meetup #6: Bring Your Own Code Coding Hour
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's R Ladies Meetup: Bring Your Own Code Open Coding Hour!

This month we are hosting an open coding night at The Rayback Collective. This is a casual meetup for people to bring their projects, practice skills, and just mingle and share tips, tricks, and expeRtise. Use this time to work through R tutorials, a TidyTuesday challenge, or your own project.

We'll be there by 5:45pm and people are welcome to hang out until Rayback closes.

Can't wait to see you all there!

title: R-Ladies Sydney: #ShutUpandCode
description:
Learning something new on your own is hard! So lets meet up and learn new R things together.

This month we are getting together at University of Sydney to meet up, shut up (talking is allowed if you are seeking/getting help), and code.

Modelled on the academic writing #ShutUpAndWrite movement (https://thesiswhisperer.com/shut-up-and-write/), the idea is make learning social.

There are only 10 places available at each session, so ONLY RSVP if you are SURE you will come. Please do not take a place from another RLady, and then not turn up.

title: R-Ladies Edinburgh: Scraping and Visualising Twitter Data
description:
In this short, hands-on workshop we are going to scrape and visualize our own Twitter data by understanding the basics of text wrangling and by taking advantage of the amazing {tidytext} and {rtweet} packages. By the end of the workshop, you will be able to see if you tweet mostly positive or negative content, and you will be able to plot the most frequent words in a wordcloud. Don't worry if you do not have your own Twitter account - there will be an alternative provided.

Anna Henschel is a third year PhD candidate at the University of Glasgow, where she conducts research in the Social Brain in Action Lab on the ERC-funded Social Robots project. She has a http://B.Sc. in Psychology from Konstanz University and a http://M.Sc. cum laude from the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam in Cognitive Neuropsychology. Her feminist activism and work as a STEM ambassador was recently honoured with the YWCA 30 Under 30 Inspirational Women Scotland award. She uses R in her PhD and also just for fun.

You can find her on Twitter (@AnnaHenschel) and check out the workshop Twitter account (@beautiful_hack).

title: R-Ladies London: Tidy up your data science workflow with the tidyverse
description:
Registration to the event is required on Eventbrite: https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/tidy-up-your-data-science-workflow-with-the-tidyverse-tickets-91446038563

RLadies London is excited to present Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel!

About the event
The tidyverse is a coherent system of packages for data manipulation, exploration and visualization that share a common design philosophy.
There are core tidyverse packages that you're likely to use in everyday data analyses, and these include:
- ggplot2
- dplyr
- tidyr
- readr
- purrr
- tibble
- stringr
- forecats
We'll be learning a bit about each of these core packages while demonstrating their functionalities!

About the speaker
Mine is a Senior Lecturer in the School of Mathematics at University of Edinburgh and Data Scientist and Professional Educator at RStudio. Mine’s work focuses on innovation in statistics and data science pedagogy, with an emphasis on computing, reproducible research, student-centered learning, and open-source education as well as pedagogical approaches for enhancing retention of women and under-represented minorities in STEM. Mine works on integrating computation into the undergraduate statistics curriculum, using reproducible research methodologies and analysis of real and complex datasets. She is a former R-Ladies RTP and a current R-Ladies Edinburgh organizer.

Agenda
18:00 Opening doors
18:30 Presentation
19:30 Networking

title: R-Ladies Miami: Intro to R Markdown
description: Join us to learn from Co-Organizer, Layla Bouzoubaa, on how to create and prepare R Markdown files within R Studio for presentations and publication ready text, output, and visualizations!

title: R-Ladies Miami: "Totally Tidy Tuning Tools" by Max Kuhn
description:
R-Ladies Miami is excited to present Max Kuhn on March 3, 2020!

Many machine learning models have hyperparameters whose values cannot be analytically estimated from the data. For example, the number of neighbors in a nearest-neighbor classification model. The tidymodels collection or R packages are a tidyverse interface to modeling. In this talk, the new tune package will be introduced. Examples of the tidy interface to model tuning will be demonstrated.

Max Kuhn is a software engineer at RStudio. He is currently working on improving R's modeling capabilities. He was a Senior Director of Nonclinical Statistics at Pfizer Global R&D in Connecticut. He was applying models in the pharmaceutical and diagnostic industries for over 18 years. Max has a Ph.D. in Biostatistics.

Max is the author of numerous R packages for techniques in machine learning and reproducible research and is an Associate Editor for the Journal of Statistical Software. He, and Kjell Johnson, wrote the book Applied Predictive Modeling, which won the Ziegel award from the American Statistical Association, which recognizes the best book reviewed in Technometrics in 2015. Their latest book, Feature Engineering and Selection, was published in 2019.

title: R-Ladies Irvine: Sports Statistics, Advancing Your Career in 2020, & R Adoption in the Enterprise
description:
# Schedule
Tuesday, March 17th, 6:30-8:30pm
6:30 - [Networking Activity] R-Ladies Networking Scavenger Hunt
6:55 - Announcements
7:00 - [Career Corner] Advancing Your Career in 2020 & R Adoption in the Enterprise
7:20 - 10-Minute Break
7:30 - [R Time] A Sports Statistics Show and Tell
8:30 - Meeting Adjourned

# Meeting Location
UC Irvine Campus
School of Medicine
Gillespie Neuroscience Research Facility
1st Floor Conference Room
Here are a few helpful maps of UCI to help you find us: https://www.parking.uci.edu/maps/map_services.cfm

# Parking
- All vehicles parked on the UC Irvine campus are required to display a valid parking permit at all times. Permit dispensers are available in all parking structures/lots at all times and accept major credit cards (Visa, MasterCard, American Express, Discover) and cash. If you don't already have a parking permit, parking is $2/hr. The closest parking lots to the event are lots 82, 83, and 84.
- Here are a few helpful maps of UCI to help you find where to park: https://www.parking.uci.edu/maps/map_services.cfm

# Food & Freebies
- Healthy vegan and gluten-free snacks and water will be provided.
- Free R-Ladies and tidyverse stickers will also be given out.

# Presentations
[Career Corner] Advancing Your Career in 2020 & R Adoption in the Enterprise
Speaker: Louis Columbus

[R Time] A Sports Statistics Show and Tell
Speaker: Jason Wilson, PhD
Abstract:
The contents of this presentation will be drawn from the qopbaseball.com project which began in 2010, two years after I completed my Ph.D in Statistics. It originated with a clever student's IntroStat class final project! The research consists of 1 patent-pending statistical model for calculating the quality of a baseball pitch, 8 million Major League Baseball (MLB) pitches calculated, 12 thousand lines of R code, 15 MLB teams consulted, and 1 active Twitter handle @qopbaseball. In the first part of the presentation (~30min.), I will tell the origin story and development, with special attention given to the R work and lessons learned along the way. The second part of the presentation (~20min.) will be guided according to audience interest. I will take questions on any aspects of the project. I will have code and data on hand for demonstration. Sample data will be provided for audience explorations.

# Live-streaming & Meeting Materials
- All announcements and presentations will be live-streamed and recorded starting at 7:00 PM. Join us at this link: https://youtu.be/2S1CO3v1g58
- All materials will be sent out and posted on our GitHub (https://github.com/rladies-irvine) after the event.

# Technology Support & WiFi
- Extension cords and outlet strips will be provided to power your devices (i.e. smartphones, tablets, laptops). Please note that bringing a device is not required to attend our meetings. **Note:** If you would like to work with the provided sports data during the meeting, please bring your laptop with R installed and a charging cable.
- Free UCI Guest WiFi will also be provided. Please use ExpressReg to register your device and connect: https://oit.uci.edu/reg
More information about connecting to UCI Guest WiFi can be found here: https://www.oit.uci.edu/mobile/registration/

title: trigeR - Trójmiejska Grupa Entuzjastów R: Deep Learning in R - part III – Convolutional Neural Networks
description:
With the release of the R Keras package (https://keras.rstudio.com/) (by JJ Allaire and Francois Chollet) at the end of 2017 / beginning 2018 the topic of artificial neural networks and especially deep learning in R became red-hot within the R community.

„Deep Learning in R” will be a series of workshops during which you will learn how to use Keras/Tensorflow to solve different deep learning problems using Feedforward, Convolutional, and Recurrent Neural Networks. During workshops we will go through problems like image classification, object localization/detection, image segmentation, dimensionality reduction, time series forecasting, various NLP tasks and more. We will also talk about interpretability of Machine/Deep Learning models using LIME and DALEX packages.

In our third workshop we will talk about Convolutional Neural Networks and transfer learning

After workshop we will have some pizza and drinks :)

Requirements:

Knowledge from first and second meeting: https://www.meetup.com/Trojmiejska-Grupa-Entuzjastow-R/events/267136487/
https://www.meetup.com/Trojmiejska-Grupa-Entuzjastow-R/events/268018583/

During workshops unfortunately there will be no internet connection so participants have to download scripts and datasets before meeting: https://github.com/maju116/trigeR_deep_learning_with_keras_in_R

title: R Glasgow: R Glasgow - February meetup
description:
Hello all, looking forward to seeing you for our February meetup with two fantastic speakers, using R in awesome and creative ways!

Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel

Mine is Senior Lecturer in the School of Mathematics at University of Edinburgh and Data Scientist and Professional Educator at RStudio. Mine’s work focuses on innovation in statistics and data science pedagogy, with an emphasis on computing, reproducible research, student-centered learning, and open-source education as well as pedagogical approaches for enhancing retention of women and under-represented minorities in STEM. Mine works on integrating computation into the undergraduate statistics curriculum, using reproducible research methodologies and analysis of real and complex datasets. You can find her at http://mine-cr.com/

Abstract: From reproducibility to interactivity: In this talk we demo a variety of authoring options in R that you can choose to add interactivity to your static reproducible computational documents using packages like rmarkdown, flexdashboard, shinydashboard, and shiny.

Anna Henschel

Anna is a third year PhD candidate at the University of Glasgow, where she conducts research in the Social Brain in Action Lab on the ERC-funded Social Robots project. She has a B.Sc. in Psychology from Konstanz University and a M.Sc. cum laude from the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam in Cognitive Neuropsychology. Her feminist activism was recently honoured with the YWCA 30 Under 30 Inspirational Women Scotland award. She uses R in her PhD and also just for fun :) You can connect with her on Twitter (@AnnaHenschel), LinkedIn and find her latest publications on her website (www.annahenschel.com).

Abstract: In this short talk, I am reflecting on fun web-scraping pRojects, specifically using the {rtweet} and {SpotifyR} packages. I will provide a walk-through of interacting with the Spotify and Twitter API, share some inspiration for possible ways we can visualize this qualitative data and also some “R-hacks” I like to use. In addition, I am going to talk about my experience of organizing a two day R-workshop (“Hack your data beautiful”) and taking over the We Are R-Ladies Rotating Curator account. I look forward to your questions!

title: R-Ladies Nijmegen: Analyse your data using GAMs in R – All levels welcome!
description:
Have you heard about generalised additive models (GAMs) and would like to know more about how to use them? Come along to this workshop to get an introduction to GAMs: what they are and when and how to use them.

This workshop will be given by Dr. Evelien Heyselaar! Evelien is an Assistant Professor in AI and Communication Science at the Radboud University.

PROGRAMME
A detailed programme will follow soon :)

Note the different day (Tuesday) and location (Orikami)!

The event will start at 18:30.
Data Scientist Inez Wijnands will start us off with an introduction to the work that Orikami does and then Evelien will tell us all about GAMs!

Drinks and snacks will be provided by Orikami.

REQUIREMENTS
Don't forget to bring your (fully charged!) laptop with R and R Studio installed.

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct -- we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment

title: R-Ladies Amsterdam: Putting your R-code into production using Docker containers
description:
Making a quick script for a model or visual in R is something we do everyday. But what if we have some kind of script, model or visual that we would like to use many times a day or make available in a robust way to many users? That's what production is about!
Nowadays, putting code into production, is a complicated story of containers, pipelines, infrastructure, clusters etc. We are going to learn the basics of how to "containerize" your code for production-ready R-coding using Docker-containers. This skill will make you ready to discuss on how to bring your R-code into production within your IT department or in any cloud-environment. We will work in small groups and go step by step so you are ready to rock your code in production!

PROGRAM
---------------
18:00 - 18:30 Welcome & Food
18:30 - 18:45 Intro RLadies and SiaPartners
18:45 - 19:30 Introduction to R in Production
19:30 - 19:45 Break
19:45 - 20:30 Workshop dockerize your R code
20:30 - 21:00 Drinks & Networking

IMPORTANT
For security reasons we need to provide a list of participants. Please use this form to submit your name https://forms.gle/916kPtLAh6qx4n9r9 .

ABOUT INDERDEEP
--------------------------
https://www.linkedin.com/in/inderdeep-singh/
Inderdeep holds a BSc degree in Econometrics from the Free University of Amsterdam and a MSc degree in Econometrics from the Erasmus University of Rotterdam. She has more than 3 years of experience applying data science methods in the insurance industry, lease companies, health care and banking industry. Inderdeep is part of the Data Science Center of Excellence at Sia Partners Amsterdam.

ABOUT SIAPARTNERS
------------------------------
https://sia-partners.com/
Sia Partners is a next-generation consulting firm focused on delivering superior value and tangible results to its clients as they navigate the digital revolution. Our global footprint and our expertise in more than 30 sectors and services allow us to enhance our clients' businesses worldwide. We guide their projects and initiatives in strategy, business transformation, IT & digital strategy, and Data Science. As the pioneer of Consulting 4.0, we develop consulting bots and integrate AI in our solutions.

REQUIREMENTS
----------------------
You should be comfortable to work with R (medium/advanced).

We will use Docker during the meetup, however, you're not required to have it installed on your laptop. We will have a number of laptops available that can be used during the workshop. However, feel free to install docker on your own laptop and bring it along.

CODE OF CONDUCT
----------------------------
We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct. Anyone who violates this community's Code of Conduct will be refused entry, expelled, and/or any other action deemed appropriate by the Organizer, regardless of event registration, meetup membership or other condition. We are emphatically queer and trans-friendly. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn.

title: EdinbR: The Edinburgh R Usergroup: Working with Tree Structures and Manipulating and visualizing weather data
description:
Hi everyone,

Our Febrary session will be on 19th, so join us from 6.00pm in Old College, Usha Kasera Lecture Theatre (https://www.ed.ac.uk/timetabling-examinations/timetabling/room-bookings/bookable-rooms3/room/0001_01_1.264) (map: https://www.openstreetmap.org/relation/33710). As usual, the meeting will be open for all to attend, and newcomers / beginners are very welcome. After the talks we'll be heading off to a pub nearby, so do come along!

Our speakers are Greg Sutcliffe and Juliette Maire. Greg is a community data scientist at Ansible and Red Hat. Juliette is a PhD student at Scotland's Rural College.

---

## Roots'n'All - Working with Tree Structures in R
### Greg Sutcliffe (https://twitter.com/Gwmngilfen)

Tree structures are common - from the files on your computer to the hierarchy of your organisation, there's a wealth of data contained both within the objects of the tree *and* the links between them. There are many questions one might wish to ask of such a tree, concerning the depth/breadth of the whole tree, or calculations across parts of it.

Working with the trees is made possible in R via the `data.tree` library, and visualization can be done with `ggraph` extensions to ggplot2. In this talk, we'll cover how to create a tree object (say, from a data frame), how to calculate some properties on each part of the tree, and how to visualize the result.

---

## Manipulating and visualizing weather data
### Juliette Maire (https://www.sruc.ac.uk/jmaire)

Large-scale weather dataset (historical or predictions) is usually a "big" multidimensional dataset that includes space, time components and various variables such as rain, temperature, wind speed. Weather dataset is often saved as NetCDF file. This talk is a quick introduction to how to simply handle such files, extract or manipulate data from it, and visualize the results in R.

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Books In Bars - How Charts Lie
description:
Spend Friday night discussing How Charts Lie (https://www.amazon.com/How-Charts-Lie-Getting-Information/dp/1324001569).

A leading data visualization expert explores the negative―and positive―influences that charts have on our perception of truth.

We’ve all heard that a picture is worth a thousand words, but what if we don’t understand what we’re looking at? Social media has made charts, infographics, and diagrams ubiquitous―and easier to share than ever. We associate charts with science and reason; the flashy visuals are both appealing and persuasive. Pie charts, maps, bar and line graphs, and scatter plots (to name a few) can better inform us, revealing patterns and trends hidden behind the numbers we encounter in our lives. In short, good charts make us smarter―if we know how to read them.

However, they can also lead us astray. Charts lie in a variety of ways―displaying incomplete or inaccurate data, suggesting misleading patterns, and concealing uncertainty―or are frequently misunderstood, such as the confusing cone of uncertainty maps shown on TV every hurricane season. To make matters worse, many of us are ill-equipped to interpret the visuals that politicians, journalists, advertisers, and even our employers present each day, enabling bad actors to easily manipulate them to promote their own agendas.

In How Charts Lie, data visualization expert Alberto Cairo teaches us to not only spot the lies in deceptive visuals, but also to take advantage of good ones to understand complex stories. Public conversations are increasingly propelled by numbers, and to make sense of them we must be able to decode and use visual information. By examining contemporary examples ranging from election-result infographics to global GDP maps and box-office record charts, How Charts Lie demystifies an essential new literacy, one that will make us better equipped to navigate our data-driven world.

PS Please contact the organizer if you need support finding the book.

title: Seattle useR Group (R Programming Language): WashPo Opioid Dataset - large data viz with R
description:
At this meetup we have an interesting presentation and training from Winston Saunders on data that is too large to fit into memory! We look forward to having you!

Abstract:
In 2019 the Washington Post successfully pursued a FOIA request for records of opiod shipments from the DEA's Automated Reporting System (ARCOS) spanning the height of the prescription opiod epidemic from 2006 to 2012. These data were subsequently published for 179 Million drug transactions ranging from mg to kilograms in size. While R's powerful analytical and visualization capabilities are, in principle, great for understanding the structure of the distribution network that enabled the epidemic, given the 78GB size of the dataset, efficient analysis required developing techniques, including data parsing and preparation of "summary" data sets, to dig deeply and thoroughly into the data. I'll share some of the techniques used to wrangle the raw data into more digestible summaries as well as the tools developed and the summaries themselves. We'll also explore how these summary data sets, coupled with mapping (ggmap), network analysis (network, igraph), and Shiny, can be used to reveal the magnitude the opiod epidemic and the network architecture, from manufacturer, to distributor, to consumer, that enabled it. To wrap up, we'll access one of the summary datasets and walk through a quick network visualization or mapping hands-on exercise. [To do the ggmaps mapping exercise you'll need your own API key from google]

Biography:
Winston is a data hackster with a day job. Though he first learned R in the Johns Hopkins Coursera pre-tidyverse he now enthusiastically embraces %>% and, nine times in ten, chooses slice(1:10) over [1:10, ]. He’s explored ML, NLP, AI, image processing, web & twitter bots, kaggle competitions, and lots of other applications in R. He selected his current project out of a balanced sense of responsibility and mischief.

If you are wanting to have your own meetup to discuss the cool ways you are using R, reach out to Ellis Hughes via Meetup.com!

title: Canberra R Users Group: AlphaZetta Global Analytics Summit - Sydney 2020
description:
Registration is required on the AlphaZetta site - links below.

The AlphaZetta Global Analytics Summit is a unique conference experience, built around experts sharing their knowledge, use cases, best practice and having time for meaningful interactions. It is not vendor driven - there’s no booths or selling and no big crowds - we expect only ~150 attendees. The summit provides insightful presentations, fantastic networking and discussion time at great value!

We are delighted that the next GAS will be held in Sydney on Friday 21st February at the Manly Pacific Hotel. Further details including the agenda can be found here ( https://alphazetta.ai/event/global-analytics-summit-sydney-2020/ ).

The day starts with presentations on the current state of the analytics market and key trends to look for in the future. The second section is about inspiring attendees with keynotes from Volt Bank on creating a new business based on data and analytics and from Raiffeisen Bank on building an analytics team to provide true value to the whole organisation.

The afternoon focuses on innovation and implementation. We have presentations from some of Australia’s exciting startups (Volt, Adgile Media, Self Assured Pty Ltd) who are using analytics to disrupt their markets. To close, we will hear a keynote on how to deliver analytics and increase AI adoption.

The Summit venue is the Novotel Pacific, Manly which is right on the ocean beach, with lunch and dinner included.

All up, at just $240 for early bird or $360 for standard tickets, it’s a conference like no other!

Presenters Include:

Steve Weston - Co-Founder and CEO, Volt Bank

Stephen Brobst - AlphaZetta Advisory Board; Chief Technology Officer, Teradata; TDWI Fellow

Felipe Flores - Founder, Data Futurology; GM Data Science and Analytics, Liberty Financial

title: R-Ladies RTP: #tidytuesday Work Group
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! Work individually or with the group and end the evening by sharing your work.

We'll explore the Australia Fires data set available here: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2020/2020-01-07 You can read more about the data set and associated online article via that link too.

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:15 pm Meet & Greet
6:15 - 7:30 pm #tidytuesday
7:30 - 8:00 pm Discussion

This is a great opportunity to meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build up your GitHub/Twitter/data science portfolio!

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post: https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together!

What should I bring?
Please bring your own laptop (fully-charged!) and all learning materials you want to use. If you have time, please look at the data set beforehand and think about some questions you'd like to answer with it.

Where will it take place?
Cocoa Cinnamon Lakewood

Will there be options to fuel up while I code?
Yes! Cocoa Cinnamon has all sorts of drinks (caffeinated and non-caffeinated) and delicious churros. On Tuesdays, the So Good Pupusas food truck will be parked outside of the coffee shop to serve up some El Salvadorian pupusas. More info here: https://www.sogoodpupusas.com/

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: R-Ladies Madison: Tidy Tuesday Kickoff
description:
A weekly data project aimed at the R ecosystem. As this project was borne out of the R4DS Online Learning Community and the R for Data Science textbook, an emphasis was placed on understanding how to summarize and arrange data to make meaningful charts with ggplot2, tidyr, dplyr, and other tools in the tidyverse ecosystem. However, any code-based methodology is welcome - just please remember to share the code used to generate the results.

title: R-Ladies Berlin: Getting started with R
description:
Hey there!

its the beginning of a new year and we are having a session for beginners... This time will be all about learning R :)

*You are already familiar with R*
come by and support the others or come and take the time to learn something you have been meaning to get a handle on for a long time!

*You are new to R and the community*
feel free to join, this is the meet-up for you!

The wonderful Lisa Hehnke (twitter: @dataplanes) will give an "Intro to R" and in our hands-on session you get to try it out yourself. Either join for some exercises or work on your own projects/ideas.

Meet Lisa
*********************************************
She is a researcher turned social data scientist who is working to address current societal challenges in order to make a difference and drive change. After obtaining her Master's degree in politics and public administration with specializations in management and quantitative research methods, Lisa worked as a researcher for computational social science and quantitative data analysis at the Universities of Konstanz, Hamburg, and Bielefeld. She currently develops a decentralized knowledge commons infrastructure with Liberate Science and serves as a steering committee member of the Open Science MOOC to make open the default setting for all global research.

Schedule:
*********************************************
18.30 - Arrival and Welcome
19.00 - Intro to R with Lisa
20.00 - Hands-on session: You can do it
20.30 - Keep going or Mingle

preparation
*********************************************
for the meet-up, try to have R and RStudio installed on your device, so that you are ready to go. If you run into problems, we can sort them out at the venue ;)

you already want to get started?
*********************************************
here are some materials with wich you can start

install.packages("swirl")
library(swirl)

contact
*********************************************
twitter: @RLadiesBerlin
please get in touch if you have any questions!

********************************************************************************
stay tuned for more details and preparation instructions :)

title: R-Ladies Helsinki: Reproducible research and how to do it with RMarkdown
description:
During this workshop, you will learn how to create reproducible research files with RMarkdown and how to share them.

We will go through the following subjects:
- Overview and structure of rmarkdown files
- Adding charts and tables to documents (PDF, HTML, etc.)
- Customize your document

Prerequisites if you want to code by yourself:
- R and RStudio installed on your machine
- Packages knitr, kable, tidyverse installed

If you want PDF documents with LaTeX you need to download:
- Windows user: MikTex (https://miktex.org/download)
- MacOS user: MacTex (https://www.tug.org/mactex/mactex-download.html)
- Linux user: Use package manager

If you want to get familiar with the subject beforehand, check this cheatsheet:
https://rstudio.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/rmarkdown-cheatsheet.pdf

See you on Monday!

title: R-Ladies London, Ontario: Intro to Shiny for interactive graphics and data visualization
description:
Join us on Feb. 11th as Emma Smith introduces us to Shiny.

Tired of presenting your research using the same old boring tables and figures? Shiny is a powerful R package that allows you to create interactive applications ranging from infographics and maps to business dashboards. This workshop will start by providing a walkthrough of the basic framework of Shiny applications, including the creation of interactive plots and tables. This will be followed by some tips on how to kick your apps up a notch using only one or two lines of code thanks to libraries such as shinyWidgets, shinydashboard, and plotly. Resources will be provided for those interested in creating more advanced dashboards or making their Shiny creations available online.

title: R-Ladies New York: timetrackR and gtsummary
description:
**Meeting location: LMHQ 150 Broadway 20th floor, New York, NY 10038**

Our speakers for the night will be Jessica Lavery and Margie Hannum from Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Jessica will be talking about the timetrackR app. Margie will be discussing the gtsummary package.

Agenda:
6:30-6:55 pm Introductions and Social Time
6:55-7 pm R-Ladies New York Announcements
7-7:10 Sponsor Message from IBM Developer New York
7:10-7:40 It's Time to Shine with timetrackR App, Jessica Lavery
7:40-8:10 Creating publication-ready and reproducible analytical tables with gtsummary, Margie Hannum
8:10-8:30 Networking

Title: It’s Time to Shine with the timetrackR App
Presenter: Jessica Lavery

Abstract: While tracking time may seem like a mundane task that in and of itself consumes your time, if monitored and assessed regularly it can be useful to create a record of your work and to identify potential areas for improving efficiency. The timetrackR Shiny app provides a high-level summary of active, inactive and upcoming projects, as well as visualizations for the percentage of time spent by project or project investigator, number of hours spent on each project, and a timeline framing each project’s trajectory from planning through analysis and manuscript preparation. With the option to filter by year, investigator and analyst, the app is versatile enough to use for an individual or for an entire team as well as for use on a regular basis and for year-end or longer-term reviews of how time was spent. I will highlight the key features of the app and demonstrate how to integrate into your current workflow.

Bio: Jessica Lavery is a Biostatistician in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. She has an MS in Biostatistics from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (2014) and as of Fall 2019 is also pursuing a doctorate in public health (DrPH) in Biostatistics at Columbia University. Her research focuses primarily on retrospective analyses using institutional and claims data sources. She also serves as the[masked] Volunteer Coordinator for the Caucus for Women in Statistics. Follow her on Twitter @jessicalavs

Title: Creating publication-ready and reproducible analytical tables with gtsummary
Presenter: Margie Hannum

Abstract: A critical aspect of many data analysis projects is presenting tables of summary statistics and regression model results. However, summarizing results into publication-ready tables often requires a lot of extra code to customize (e.g. create reference line for categorical variables, format p-values a certain way, bold variable labels, merge multiple model results into one table, etc.). The {gtsummary} package provides an elegant and flexible way to make summary and analytic tables in R. Written as a companion to the {gt} package from RStudio, the {gtsummary} package summarizes data sets, regression models, and more, using sensible defaults with highly customizable capabilities. It also allows you to pull values straight from these tables for use in inline text so that every portion of your R markdown analysis report is reproducible. This talk will go over the functionality of the {gtsummary} package, and how you can use it to create beautifully formatted, ready-to-share summary and result tables in a single line of R code.

Bio: Margie Hannum is a Biostatistician at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics. Her research collaborations largely involve using multi-modal genomic and single cell data to characterize cancer subpopulations. She contributes to the {gtsummary} package and uses it every day in her analysis pipelines. Twitter: @Margaret_Hannum

title: R-Ladies Den Bosch: **NEW DATE** R Markdown – Composing Reproducible Documents with Graphs & Tables
description:
We are excited to invite you to our first event of 2020!
During this event, Martine Jansen will give a workshop on R Markdown. R Markdown provides a way to integrate code and report content into high quality documents. R Markdown documents are fully reproducible and support dozens of output formats. In this workshop we will create an R Markdown document, in which we use the tidyverse to read a csv and manipulate it. After adding some analyses and plots, we will write inline R code, so the text in the report changes depending on the data. We present the resulting analysis with one click in a nicely formatted Word document. After this workshop you will have the tools to start your own analysis projects with RStudio.

Martine Jansen works for Fontys University of Applied Sciences as an institutional researcher. Another form of this workshop was presented at the EAIR forum 2019 in Leiden and at R-Ladies Amsterdam.

**PLEASE NOTE THE CHANGED DATE**

Date: Tuesday, February 18th, 2020
Starting time: 6PM
Location: Avans Hogeschool Den Bosch (walking distance from train station)
Schedule to be announced

As a local R-Ladies chapter, we want to host accessible workshops and create a community of R-enthusiasts where everyone can develop their R skills. Everyone who is interested in the R language and supports inclusion in the community is welcome to join.

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct -- we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment
https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

Looking forward to meeting all of you!
-- Organizing team R-Ladies Den Bosch

title: R-Ladies Medellín: Segundo Encuentro R-Ladies Medellín: Visualización de datos con ggplot2
description:
Una de las habilidades más importantes para la ciencia de datos es la creación de gráficos útiles y llamativos que permitan comunicar información significativa contenida en nuestras bases de datos. ggplot 2 es un paquete de visualización de datos del lenguaje de programación R. En este taller usaremos este paquete para analizar una base de datos que corresponde a los resultados de la Encuesta de la Juventud realizada en la Cuidad de Medellín.

Para este taller es necesario traer tu computador y tener previamente instalado R y RStudio. Para mayor información sobre el proceso de instalación consulta este link: https://www.datacamp.com/community/news/install-r-and-rstudio-a-step-by-step-guide-for-beginners-q498j0akyh
